I rose before three this morning, an hour earlier than my regular time, supposing that to have arrived at 40 minutes past 3 I saw Sirius about 10 minutes risen— I mark the 10th. of August as the day, and 40 minutes past 4 as the time of his emerging so far from his conjunction with the Sun that the Egyptian shepherds would have discovered him.— One of the obstacles to my morning labours now is the moisture of all grass covered ground, on which whether from dew or rain I cannot tread without getting wet-feet, from which no leather boot or shoe affords protection. The bare foot or the Sabot is the proper chaussure of the practical farmer.— This morning, after a long and fruitless search for the papers which I had prepared in 1839 for ascertaining the amount of the claim of the Administration of Moses Gill on that of Thomas Boylston, I was obliged without finding them to go into Boston and attend the probate Court. Mr Fuller was not there— I told the judge that I had not found the papers, but would as soon as possible either find them, or make out from the correspondence a statement of the amount as I had done before— I called at the Store of Mr Curtis’s son in State Street, to enquire if he was in town; and to inform him that I wished to see him at my Son’s Office— I went twice there and desired Mr Spooner, if Mr Curtis should come in to inform him that I should be glad to see him there to-morrow— I called at the Emancipator Office, where Mr Leavitt had a large volume Class B. of paper laid by the British Government, before Parliament relating to the Slave trade in 1842. He says there are three more such volumes Class A. C. and D—which he expects to receive by the next Steamer.— There came up a heavy shower, and I purchased an Umbrella—the first volume of the Lives of the Queens of England by Agnes Strickland, and the Hymns of the Nursery of England; which I gave to Charles’s son Henry— As I was standing at the door of the Booksellers shop Dr Frothingham in passing by stop’d and spoke to me. At Mr James H. Foster I saw Mrs Foster and Louisa. Mary was quite unwell and kept her chamber. The Quincy Stage took me up there and landed me at home before 2.— As we were sitting down to dinner Mr P. Bronson of Auburn, New-York called to see me— He had already called this morning with his nephew Mr William Blake of Boston, just after I had left home in the Stage— Mr Blake returned to Boston— Mr Bronson remained to see me before his departure to return home— He was to go in the Stage this afternoon to Hingham: thence in the Steamer to Boston, and there to take the Cars of the Great Western Railroad to Albany.— Mr Bronson was one of the Gentleman, who with Governor William H Seward accompanied me from Auburn to Syracuse. I received this morning a Letter of the 21st. instant from Genl. Peter B Porter at Niagara, with a copy of one of 8 June last from him to Governor Bouck.

div.dateline: Quincy Tuesday 29 August 1843 Boston and back.
div.p: 29 III.50 Tuesday.

To keep up the current of my diary, I omitted the morning excursion to my garden and grounds. at 10. I rode with Louisa C. Smith to Boston, and left her at Mr James H. Foster’s. Visited Mr Robert C. Winthrop— Mr and Mrs Kennedy left the city yesterday morning for the Saratoga Springs. I spoke to Mr Winthrop of the removal by John Tyler of Levi Lincoln, from the Office of Collector of the Port of Boston; and the appointment of Robert Rantoul junr. in his place; and enquired whether the merchants of Boston would not as a body take some notice of this dirty trick of the accidental President. He said he thought it would be very proper, but although Mr Lincoln is universally allowed to have discharged in exemplary manner the duties of the Office; there is little sympathy with him in the public mind on this occasion. At my Son’s office I found Mr Spooner, Mr Flint of Louisville Kentucky and Mr. Nathaniel Curtis. Mr Flint who proposes to depart to-morrow on his return to Louisville, urged on me again the acceptance of his invitation to me to visit that city, when I go to Cincinnati next November, but I told him it was exceedingly doubtful whether I shall be able to go even to Cincinnati, and if I do, whether I can extend my journey further.— I left him however with an assurance that I will come to Louisville if I can— I requested Mr Curtis to look over his papers to see if he has not among them some memoranda of the amount of the Gill claim on the Thomas Boylston administration— He shewed me a proposal from the present Tenant of the School Street house, that it be taken down, and a new one built on the site, for which he shall take a lease for 5. or 10 years at a rent of 1000 dollars a year— We discussed and referred it for further consideration. I signed a duplicate of the Letter of the 15th. instt. to Petty Vaughan. President Quincy passing in his chaise in the Street, stop’d and spoke to me. I had received from him this morning sundry papers relating to the observatory.— He recommended specially Professor Peirce to my attention— Going to visit Dr George Parkman I met him in the Street, and went with him to his house where I saw Mrs and Miss Parkman, a Miss Brown and Alexander H. Everett— The Doctor walked with me to judge Davis’s house. There I dined with his daughters Mrs Goodwin and Mrswidows Isaac P. Davis and his wife, Professor Peirce, and Tutor Lovering.— We had much conversation on Astronomy— I urged the judge to get up an Astronomical Society in Boston— At 5. pm the carriage came: I took up Louisa C Smith at Mr James H Foster’s and we returned home. Mrs Charles spent the Evening here. Revised the Letter to Bangor
30. V. Wednesday.

Spading one hour— Loosened the ground round the Apple seedling in front of my Library window— Deacon Spear was here to speak of the payment of my annual tax-bill—Town and County— A deduction of 4 per cent for payment on or before the first of September— My Son has the bill— We expected his return home this day; but he did not arrive— Captain Josiah Bass’s Son has four lots of woodland 50 acres in all, which he wants to sell, but names no asking price. I required that the precise quantity of the land should be ascertained, and the price specified—after which I promised to go and look at the lots.— Mrs. Martha is the widow of Lemuel Burrell, a Seaman on board the Macedonian frigate, and died in the service at Norfolk, Virginia— She has received the widow’s pension 5 years 72 dollars a year; but it was stop’d last January when she received 12 dollars as a final payment— She is in great want of a renewal of the pension, and desires to petition Congress for it. I advised her to petition jointly with as many other widows having the same ground of claim as her own, as she could find out, and I promised to present the petition and give it all the support in my power. She is a daughter of Joseph Beale heretofore of Squantum, and lives now with her daughter, wife of Richard Newcomb of this town— Mr Peirce Perkins professor of Astronomer at Harvard University, and Mr Bond, Observer for the observatory, which is to be came from Cambridge and dined with me— Mr Bond brought with him some papers additional to those which President Quincy had sent me— The successors of Frauenhofer at Munich are Merz an Optician, and Mahler a Mechanician— The price of the duplicate of the Pulkova Telescope is 42000 German florins, or 16800 dollars— On their Catalogue for sale there is a graduation of the prices of Refractors of inferior power—of 30,000. 22000. 15000— 8000. 4800. 2200. 2000 1500. 900. and 750 florins— And a multitude of other mathematical and optical instruments the most costly of which is the Heliometer charged at 15000 florins. Of this there is one at Pulkova— The mural circle is the next dearest astronomical instrument, after the Refractor. Its chief use is for making catalogues of Stars, and it requires two observers to be constantly occupied at the same time— They do not propose to procure at present a mural circle, or to make that Class of Observations at Cambridge— The Perkins professorship of Astronomy and Mathematics is a new institution at Harvard, and Mr Peirce has been this year appointed the first professor.— Mr Bond left with me two pamphlets—one in French F G. G. Struve’s report of his observations of double Stars, with Frauenhofer’s great Telescope at Dorpat from 1824 to 1837. Struve being then Director of the Dorpat Observatory.— The other is an Additamentum, in Latin, dated 2. Octr. 1839. when Struve had been transferred to the new Observatory at Pulkova; and with which there is appended a disquisition on the annual parallax of the Star [symbols] Lyrae— I collected from this interview much desultory information which I must tax my memory to retain, but which I cannot record. I took them up to Charles’s house to shew them the prospect— Met there Mr and Mrs Edmund Quincy on a visit from Dedham— Edward Brooks junr. and Thomas Frothingham came out afterwards and spent the Evening with us.
31. II.30. Thursday.

Spading and hoeing 2. hours— The Pear tree first bearing in the centre of the garden next the red cherry tree, is a bergamot— I took up the diseased peach tree close to the fence at the kitchen garden gate— In attempting to trim the wild cherry seedling up the hill, I cut off the stem itself close to the ground.— Broke up the ground sloping down from the tool box towards the orchard— Deacon Spear was here again enquiring for my Son, and about paying to Lewis Bass, collector of the town and County tax, to-morrow to save the deduction of 4 per cent for prompt payment. My Son had not then returned from his excursion, with William C. Johnson to Barnstable, Provincetown, Sandwich, Wood’s hole, Nantucket and New-Bedford— But they got home before dinner, and were here this evening.— President Quincy called on me and said he had been to the grave yard to see to the repairing of his monument of his father and mother— It has been erected about 40 years, and I wrote the epitaph engraved upon it. It is already dilapidated, in consequence of its exposure to Sun, rain, frost snow and mischievous boys— The cemetery has been much neglected, but more care of it is now taken— Mr Daniel Greenleaf called in and said that the tomb of the Ministers of the parish had been opened to deposit there the remains of the late Pastor Peter Whitney, who died on thelast and that the coffin of Norton Quincy was there placed on that of Anthony Wibird the immediate predecessor of Peter Whitney— But there was no inscription on the Stone of the name of either. That of Mr Wibird was now to be carved on it, and Mr Greenleaf enquired if I should wish to have that of Norton Quincy added to it. I said I should; and requested Mr Greenleaf to say to Mr Lunt that I would see him on the subject. I had further conversation with Mr Quincy concerning the observatory, and he is to send me some other papers accidentally omitted when he sent me the others— I read the french pamphlet report of Struve to the Minister of public instruction and President of the Russian Imperial Academy of Sciences Ouvaroff, containing the narrative of his observations upon double stars at Dorpat from 1824 to 1837. It is full of very interesting information, leading as usual to multitudes of further enquiries which I shall never have time to pursure—for see now the distribution of my time, through this month of August since the 5th. when I came home.

Day. I rise between 4 and 5. with exceptions— Sometimes not till 6. oftener between 3 and 4. this very morning at half past 2. with a disabling and disheartening headache— It takes me an hour to wash face, head hands, arms, feet, legs, and to scrubb the whole body with a mohair mitten, and then dress— Two hours idle work in and about the garden— Receive the Mail, and read Letters and newspapers— Breakfast at 8.— From that till dinner at 2. write a page of diary, with interruptions of business, of visitors and of dilly dallying idleness casually and continually occurring. After dinner—pause or sleep, one hour— Write, with interruptions as before a second page of diary. Up the hill to see the Sun rise or set, when fair.— Tea at Sunset. Evening with my family.
